content:
Posted: November 10, 2014
In BriefMind: Path to Thalamus is a flawed walk-'em-up with puzzle elements, but it is so, so very pretty that it is worth playing on that basis alone.Most valuable resource: The art.  Oh my heavens the art.  Mind is the most artistically beautiful game I've ever played.Of interest to: people who enjoyed Dear Esther and Myst.What a conflicting game.  Mind brings to mind first and foremost Dear Esther.  Both are tales of a man exploring the concept of loss through imagery and an internal journey across a landscape painted in his own memories.  However there is just as strong a link to Myst: an adventure game where progress is driven by puzzle solving, but where primacy is given to the stunning backgrounds and fantastic, surreal locations through which you find yourself traveling.  The couple of moments of full video integration into the game (which is done supremely well and to great effect) really do evoke the groundbreaking work of the Millers.Before I mention the flaws in this game - and boy are there some whomping great big flaws - I want to call attention to the visuals.  The quality of the art in this game is exceptional.  The whole artistic theme of the game, throughout all the puzzles, all the narrative sequences, right up to the closing credits, is faultless.  Every single part of the world is composed expertly in all directions, including the sky above and the ground beneath your feet (and sometimes also the sky beneath your feet).  If you completely excised the story, the art alone would make for a worthy experience, like walking slowly through a surrealist art exhibition.  I took so many screenshots while playing that I felt like a tourist taking happy snaps.  If they release a big glossy coffee table book of the art from this game I would pay real money for it.  If you're a pixel ♥♥♥♥♥ who gets off on stunning, striking, truly gorgeous art, this game is worth the entry fee on that basis alone.However - and this is a big however - there are several serious flaws with this game which take away from the experience in very significant ways.  As with my review of The Moon Sliver, another worthy but flawed narrative game, I hope that by preparing you for those flaws in advance they will not reduce your enjoyment of the game to the degree they did mine.The first issue is purely one of game design.  The puzzles in this game revolve around moving these gorgeous glowing woven wicker spheres to different places on the map, and about a third of the time you're in the game (or more if you find the puzzles a struggle involving a lot of trial and error, as I did) you'll be carrying one of these spheres, and when you pick one up it fills the centre of the screen, making it hard or sometimes impossible to see what's right in front of you.  In a game as strongly visual as this (and one with so many bottomless holes in the terrain), the decision to give the player what amounts to cataracts for a good portion of the time is a terrible, terrible one.The second major issue is the story, or rather the telling of it.  Without any spoilers, the premise is so incredibly familiar that within the first two scenes of the game you will believe you know the entire plot, and you will be correct.  I'll compare it to Dear Esther again because that's just the most applicable benchmark game when it comes to this type of storytelling.  In Dear Esther the whole game is a blur of the real and the imaginary, you're never sure whether the protagonist is projecting onto his environment or experiencing fantastic elements in his own mind.  Even at the very conclusion of that game those questions are never really answered; it is up to you, the player, to consider the narrative and interpret what you have just experienced and to arrive at an understanding of the game yourself.  The story is masterfully constructed, and respects the old writer's adage that it is better to show than to tell.The writers of Mind: Path to Thalamus set up some imagery that is intended to communicate the bigger themes and questions to the player, but then they convey it all so heavy-handedly that they practically bludgeon you over the head with it.  The biggest spoiler you will ever read for this game is the title of the game itself.  There is a sequence towards the end of the game where all the imagery up to that point is literally explained to you - they have a voice-over sequence that literally lists the metaphors you've encountered and tells you what each one meant.  It is atrocious.  In a game that is visually so subtle and well composed it causes me actual pain to see the story - whose premise is not original but is certainly not bad, and is certainly worth exploring - butchered so bluntly.  Either the authors were so keen that their lovingly-crafted narrative be understood that they could not help but explain it, or they lacked confidence in their writing and over-compensated, or they thought so little of their audience that they felt they needed to be spoon-fed.  I charitably hope it's the former; I hope it's not a case of an auteur game designer too wrapped up in himself to allow the players to control their own experience of his artistic creation lest they experience it wrong.  Whatever the medium, good artistic narrative flows naturally; if you need to put it on rails, you've not crafted the narrative well enough.Although all credit to the developers for the way they handled the release; it has to be noted that when community feedback suggested the story was a bit pretentious, and "too wanky", they responded to the critique like true professionals, took that information on board, and deployed changes to the game when there really was no expectation that they would, or should, so they deserve props for that.  For such a new, loose collective they managed such an ambitious project, and its release, impeccably.However putting those two concerns aside, the game is a perfect length and is technically without problems (except for a little screen tearing I couldn't resolve), the puzzles have a gentle gradient that offers a fairly unique challenge that is the perfect mix of simple mechanics guided by logical, deductive reasoning, and as much as the conclusion of the story is mishandled, the final scenes in the game are visually and in terms of gameplay truly epic.  Get Mind: Path to Thalamus to experience walking through a gorgeously detailed, artistically flawless, stunningly beautiful surreal landscape, while dealing with organic, natural, thoughtful puzzles.  If you prepare yourself for the issues with the narrative you will be able to put that aside and just enjoy what is - and I can't use this word enough - the most artistically gorgeous game I've played.Support this game and these developers; even though Mind: Path to Thalamus is flawed, it is still a great game, highly recommended, and the sort of game we need more of.

content:
Posted: January 30, 2015
												This really is something special.  It's also clearly had a lot of love and care lavished on it, and it shows in the numerous updates since the game has launched to address criticism, and fine-tune the gameplay mechanics.Mind: Path To Thalamus is a really difficult game to nail down.  It could be erroneously referred to as either a puzzle game or (ugh) a "walking simulator", but neither would do the experience justice.  Sure, violence is conspicuously absent, and the main mechanical thrust of the game is solving some very clever (but never obtuse or frustrating) puzzles.  However, the game feels like much more than this, due to a very clear narrative thread that ties the various parts of the experience together, making a variety of visually stunning yet disparate environments form parts of an epic journey towards the Thalamus of the title.Of particular note is the frozen tsunami towards the end, which stands out as one of the most visually striking game environments in recent memory, although Mind is full of surreal and mind-bogglingly beautiful environments.  You'll traverse huge expanses of dreamlike field, navigate impossible geometry, fight a behemoth hundreds of feet high, and alter the environment itself.In spite of various criticisms, I also feel the narrative deserves praise for touching on the themes of bereavement and family tragedy in a manner notably absent of sensationalism or tokenism.  You never feel like the game is feeding you sentimentality, which it easily could have.  Although the voice-acting can come across as rather melodramatic, the story being told feels low-key and relatable.All in all, this is a fantastic purchase - a visual tour-de-force with finely honed puzzle-solving gameplay, good story, and a beautiful licensed soundtrack.  Recommended without a shadow of a doubt.

content:
Posted: March 26, 2015
												Mind is a beautiful atmospheric puzzle game. In a way it reminds me of games like Dear Esther and Myst where the goal about getting to the end but enjoying the journey.  That said, the levels  are very linear. Ubiquitous hidden walls make the game feel more like a guided tour than  an open exploration. That said, there are still plenty of stunning environments to appreciate. Most of the challenges in the game revolve around understanding and manipulating various aspects of your surroundings.  For example, you might need to change day to night or create rain to access certain areas of the level. The main way of doing this is carrying around large balls which supposedly represent a cluster of neurons. Unfortunately,  this is where one of the games' major flaws comes in. The ball itself is extremely large and obstructs most of your view, making it difficult to maneuver at times. Add to this the fact that pieces of the landscape will frequently catch on the ball, ripping it out of your grip at the worst possible time. But despite all this, it is clear that a lot of love and care went into the baking of this game. It is easy to be drawn into the story as you begin to piece together the various bits from snatches of voice-over. It also bares repeating that the game is visually stunning. Any number of the environments could be considered works of art. If you ignore some of the rough edges here and there then Mind is a short and enjoyable experience.

content:
Posted: August 24, 2014
												Though I may sound a little critical, I am definitely recommending this game to those who like exploration, puzzle, and highly narrative games.  It may not appeal to everyone, but those who enjoy this type of game will find it worth their while, even if it is only a short while.As you can probably tell, this game has a strong narrative.  The story is well constructed, and is told very well.  It's not a groundbreaker, but it's easy to care about the character and his struggle.Gameplay-wise, this is a little mixed.  I definitely enjoyed it, though some of the puzzles could be frustrating.  Fairly often I found myself concentrating so hard on the puzzles, especially later in the game, that I had to consciously step back and take in the visuals and atmosphere.  This isn't necessarily good nor bad overall, but I personally would have preferred a little more journey and exploration, and a little less puzzle.  Nothing wrong with puzzles, but the game becomes fairly well saturated with them before long.  Also, when you're carrying things, which is often, they take up most of the screen, blocking out much of the breathtaking visuals.When navigating the terrain, you'll often collide for no apparent reason, but it's not so bad that it ruins anything.  You're always able to get to where you're going.All in all, I had fun playing the game.  Some may complain about how short it is, but I find the older I get, the less time I have to sit and complete something.  So these shorter games are very welcome additions to my library.  While it seems to lack some polish, you'll still look back once you've finished the game and deem it time well spent.

Posted: September 5, 2016
												I wanted to love this game but just couldn't. Yes, it's beautiful. The strength of this game is in its dreamy, neoclassical landscapes that feel like you're wandering through an oil painting. But you can experience most of that beauty in a screenshot. In game, it feels hollow, stretched over an obtuse, lukewarm story and halfhearted puzzle elements that never quite reach Talos Principle levels of satisfaction.The biggest detriment, though, is the sound design. In a game that should feel immersive, the silences are glaringly awkward, punctuated by crashes and screeches set to jumpscare volumes. Meanwhile, the sparse dialogue sound like a mouse monologuing from inside a tin can. They didn't feel like surrealist choices to me. They just felt underproduced.If you go into this game anticipating a well rendered walking simulator instead of a story-driven first-person puzzler, you'll probably get more enjoyment from the game than I did. I don't regret the purchase, but I wish the game had matched its visuals with a better narrative and gameplay.

content:
Posted: September 21, 2016
												An occasionally great looking game that suffers greatly from an uninteresting story, questionable design choices and technical difficulties.At times the levels look good (sometimes even amazing) and other times it brings me back to the 90’s where long hallways with repeating textures where commonplace. The quality of the levels is inconsistent to say the least. Even the pretty levels quickly lose their appeal if you walk from the ball to the place to put the ball. Walking through these fast landscapes becomes tedium quickly. I feel that with better level design they could have prevented the walking simulator tag.MIND had some weird bugs for me that I find hard to believe no-one in testing noticed. Once, I reloaded a level I couldn’t find the solution to and it suddenly turned nighttime (now finishing it was easy). I was able to ‘quake-jump’ up mountains, around portals and up the whirlwinds, sometimes allowing me to create my own shortcuts. Looking down allows the camera to clip through walls.Whilst I feel that the voice actor did his best with the material given to him, the story failed to make me care about the characters. Being in a coma with regrets seems to be a popular theme in walking simulators, to the point where it almost seems cliché.When a level has weird mechanics, or a giant colossus slowly stomping towards you, the game is genuinely interesting. When it’s not, it’s bland and sometimes tedious.

At first I thought it may have been the FOV, but after messing around with the FOV settings several times I concluded that wasn't the issue. I wish there had been a way to adjust the camera height. You're playing as a grown adult man but it feels like you're crawling on the floor for most of the game. It made my personal experience quite unpleasant, though from reading other reviews I seem to be the only person who had this kind of issue.As for the rest of the game... It's nice but nothing to write home about. The puzzles weren't overly impressive, the story is so-so, and the game is severely lacking some kind of sprint button. I feel like that option isn't available to us because of how short the game is, so sprinting was removed to artificially increase the length of the game. And not being able to sprint really made some areas tedious.For me the ending really dragged on too. It was likely trying to be artistic and evocative but for me it just came off as annoying.The majority of users seem to have had a positive experience with this game, and I'm truly envious of that and happy for them, but based on my own personal experience I just can't recommend this game.

content:
Posted: January 3, 2015
												Made by Spanish developers, Mind: Path to Thalamus is a game that looks like it will be a "walking simulator" (an atmospheric adventure based on exploration) but turns out to be just as much a first-person puzzle-platformer that took me 6-7 hours to finish.  Let's imagine for a minute that everyone accepts Portal as the best first person puzzle game and Gone Home as the best exploratory adventure, even if that's not true.Mind's title is a clumsy reference to memory or consciousness, as this is a story about your sister, your daughter, your father, a tragedy or two, and a coma. Unlike Gone Home, you don't find pieces of the story or read anything.  It's all told through fragments of voiceover as you progress.  The story isn't as interesting (or clear) as in Gone Home, so it doesn't compel you to move forward as much as it could, mainly because it's all pretty abstract.What will drive you forward is the desire to figure out each environmental puzzle so you can see the next breathtaking area.  The sights are amazing, so it's a bit surprising when you start to realize they are huge environmental puzzles.  There are elements of physics and jumping involved, but your only real way to manipulate the world is in where you walk and where you place a series of spheres you find in each level after passing the first few areas of the game.The puzzle design ranges from good to great, but not consistently great (by comparison, I'd say Portal and Portal 2 had consistently great puzzles).  There are red herrings and glitches and some twitchy physics which end up making you feel really smart but also a little lucky or relieved when an area turns frustrating because you keep dropping the sphere when you run into things, missing timed jumps, or wondering if you broke the level and need to restart.  These types of puzzles are most satisfying when you can see the rules of the world, figure out a plan, and execute it (see Portal).  Mind has some of those moments and, for me, others where I'm not sure if I did what the developers expected.  All in all, though, there are clever clues that point to a solution and there are fail-safes in place that usually keep levels from breaking.The final confrontation, if I am to avoid any worse spoilers than the Steam achievements themselves, is far too much like a boss battle for this kind of game, and more than any other levels, the several battle-themed levels feel unfair and frustrating.  I was glad to finish them and the payoff wasn't worth it.  The developers included several achievements for not getting killed in these levels and I didn't get any of them.  Good luck with that.In conclusion, the graphics are impressive, smooth and colorful and the puzzle progression is unique.  The puzzles are almost great even though the story is not.  I can see people buying this game and quitting as soon as they realize it's a series of brain teasers, so be warned.  On the other hand, if you want a pure Portal clone, there are other first-person puzzlers out there that are probably less aggravating.  If, however, you've wished that all those walking simulators would replace some of the story with some environmental puzzles, this game is a beautiful choice.

Overall, this is the game that you can show to your friend who hates all computer games and thinks they're for infantile imbeciles only.Yes, it is far from perfect. Yes, the flow does get broken in places, because you're just not used to this kind of puzzles (and there's one super irritating jump to make). But as a surreal first person puzzlers go, it is brilliant. I fully expect it to be surpassed pretty soon though, as every other genre-first was surpassed in its time. And it is great! First person gaming was becoming too stagnant, too predictable, too dumb, but with games like this one it's getting exciting again.

content:
Posted: April 23
												Aesthetically, this is a superb game - the visuals and the OST are astonishingly outstanding. In fact, the MIND world was so immersive, I wouldn't mind if it were a pure walking simulator with no actual gameplay at all, because what the environment and the atmosphere of the game delivered had already exceeded my expectation and impressed me thoroughly. It's so beautifully crafted that it can potentially relieve stress and anxiety, just as it did for me. Imagine walking on a vast meadow along a clear stream, listening to the sound of pouring rain, accompanied by the gentle thunder every now and then...nothing beats this kind of feelings my friend.However, if I have to comment on the gameplay, I would say, it's far less satisfying as the aesthetics. After all, this is mostly a puzzle game, whose genre relies heavily on level design and mechanics, but sadly, it falls short on these very aspects in my opinion. The levels feel like kind of a mess - some are very short, just go through a couple of portals and you're done, while some are fairly challenging, you might need to figure out a specific sequence of actions and time your moves as well. Normally, you would expect the difficulty and the length of a level to gradually increase, instead of being random or taking leaps, but in MIND, the pacing does feel a little bit off. As for the mechanics, they're interesting and quite esay to grasp. The problem is, there're only 4 main types of puzzles throughout the 4-5 hours of experience, which could get a bit repetitive as you progress further, and there's not much of out-of-the-box thinking involved, besides following the rules and control your timing. Overall, the gameplay is alright, it's just not that impressive. When it comes to the story, I don't have much to say - you'll find fragments of memories or thoughts of the main character in the game which slowly unveil the whole plot. In short, the story follows the protagonist's journey through his uncousious mind and his inner struggle of finding peace and forgiveness which awakes him from his coma and brings him back to his counsiousness. There're also some technical issues I want to point out. First of all, it's the optimization. My PC has no problem running other much more system demanding games but it gets a low general fps on this one and some frame drops from time to time. Another one is the subtitles, some disappear too quickly, some have no spacings, and there're also some being complete nonsense. It doesn't affect the experience but it wouldn't hurt fixing them right? I also found a bug in one of the extra Halloween levels, in which an element needed for solving the puzzle kept dispawning, making it impossible to progress, and eventually I gave up trying.That's all I have to say about MIND: Path to Thalamus. Despite its flaws, I did enjoy it and I recommend it to those who care for an atmospheric, light-hearted experience.

												I love this game.PROS:Performs very well on my 'VR ready' PC - smooth with high frame rates.Looks gorgeous.Nice music.Refreshingly non-violent, emotional journey; with some really magical and relaxing sections.Supports the Vive HMD natively.Supports WASD input so I can use the Virtuix Omni and move naturally without sim-sickness.Can quickly switch between levels from the outset.CONS:A recent update seems to have introduced a bug on the first level that makes my POV too high - hope that'll get fixed soon.Doesn't have hand tracking via the Vive controllers (it was developed before these were available, so that's understandable).The puzzle solving may not be to everyone's liking (this is not an action game, and is focussed on atmosphere - it may feel sparse to some), but I enjoy it and for me this game is more about the feels anyway.Doesn't use the Omni's SDK for fully-decoupled navigation (this has only just been released, so wouldn't expect it to yet).One of the mechanics in the game (where you get flung across distances by something) isn't very VR friendly, but again this game was not originally developed for VR, so this is to be expected.Be aware this game has free-roaming locomotion (the best kind!) and so you may experience sim-sickness if you don't have a motion platform like the Virtuix Omni. Unfortunately, some people may be giving this game a worse review than it deserves because A) They're not playing it in VR, so not getting the atmosphere, B) They're playing it in VR but without a motion platform so they're getting sick. Not criticizing those reviews, just noting it's a bit sad to see this game get a lower score than I would expect from my experience of it.I recommend getting an Omni to play this (and many other games), so you can turn off the chaperone lines safely, and there is even a way to remove the floor outline for maximum immersion. content:
Posted: January 9, 2015
												Mind: Path to Thalamus is described as a surreal first person puzzler in which you control your environment to advance. But is it really so? Let's find out.The game follows the psychological journey of a comatose man through his own mind to reach conciousness. You will visit strange landscapes where you will be required to solve puzzles to advance. As you solve them, the man itself will reveal glimpses of what happened. Decent yet predictable story and good voice acting. No complains on this point.Let's move on to gameplay mechanics. You are suposed to change the weather to solve the puzzles, and you do it by placing yourself or some balls you will find in certain easily identifiable places. The way it helps you follows some weird logic, but a logic after all, and considering the setting of the game, this is not necessary a bad thing. I mean that the efects of the elements you control are not what you would expect. For example, fog removes some barriers, and night reveals some objects and activates teleportation gateways. In the end, the puzzles are reduced to find the balls and place them in the right order. In my opinion, this oversimplifies the game. I would have prefered that they came up with a more elaborated way of controling the environment. Another problem I see here is that the puzzles don't start to get hard until almost the end of the game.On the audiovisual aspect, I cannot but praise the developers. The game is really beatiful, the landscapes are well designed (although some better than others), and the atmospheric sounds get you into the game.In conclusion, I would say Mind: Path to Thalamus is a good game, with awesome ideas but with a gameplay not implemented in the best way. It is still fun to walk around and solve the puzzles (especially the last ones), but considering the duration (around 4 hours), my opinion is that the price is not worth the experience. I'm giving thumbs up because I enjoyed the game, but having payed 3€, not 13€. If you like first person puzzles, this is a quite good one, and I recommend it if it goes on sale. At full price, think twice.

Posted: November 30, 2014
												Mind: Path to Thalamus is a puzzle game with a narrative. I was on the fence about buying it, as I thought it would be another "walking simulator" of just walking through a story line, but ended up buying it on a sale. (TL;DR pro/con list at the end)I was completely off on the "just another walking simulator" notion. The types of puzzles in this game are original, well thought out and progress in difficulty. There was only one puzzle near the end that I had to look up, but I was close and I would've gotten it with a bit more time. The puzzles involve four different "areas" where you can place an orb to accomplish something:- Night, which allows you to use gate "portals" to teleport to other "portals" and allows you to use a second orb that's only available in night "mode"- Storm, which raises platforms to allow you to access higher areas or cross gaps- Past, which rebuilds broken structures- Fog The Scenery is amazing and almost every level is screenshot-worthy. I was really blown away with the visuals.Here's a list of pros and cons:Pros:- Amazing visuals- Pretty good story line- Original, fun puzzlesCons:- A couple puzzles may make you feel lost like you don't know what to do next. obviously it's a puzzle and it's expected, but I can think of one level that was somewhat large and I felt lost for a bit.- Somewhat short. Obviously playtimes will vary based on how fast someone can solve the puzzles, achievement hunting, looking at scenary, etc, but I was expecting more.tl;dr: Awesome game - unique and fun puzzles with a great story and narration, but somewhat short. If you're on the fence about this game, pick it up on sale.

content:
Posted: January 15, 2015
												I recommend this game to puzzlers, and people who can appreciate the good moments without being dragged down too much by the... lame ones.The puzzles are brilliant - top class in my opinion. They get steadily more tricky, and will have you thinking how to solve them for a few minutes (at least). The "four mirrors" in the desert, especially, were just gorgeous. Art in puzzle form, elegant, confusing, mind twisting. (but not at all frustrating)The puzzles though, are not in every level. Sure you have to "solve" a few levels, but mostly they're rather pathetic puzzles of the form "find the ball". About 1/5 of the levels are good puzzles, the rest are walking simulator/find the ball.Art varies in a similar way. Some of the levels will take your breath away - espcially on load, when the "viewpoint" is so perfectly chosen it could be a painting. The other levels are interesting/pretty, but not in the same league. Once again, it's a mixture, some of the levels look superb, some are boring. I'd maybe say half-half here, so more consistent art than puzzles.Level-character interaction is probably the weakest part of the game. Some points have you walking excessively long boring tunnels or grasslands for no real benefit, or "exploring" fog because you chanced to miss a fog ball. These long dry patches detracted and "bordered on boredom" at times.Music is passable, narration is... weird. It's an intersting story (kind of cliche but it works, and that's ok), and it ties things together... a bit. Come for the puzzles and the occasionally breathtaking artwork.In summary, the game is partly superb, and partly dull. If you can gloss over the dull parts (and make no mistake, they're not bad - just boring), you'll be left with excellent memories of pretty environments and aha-moment puzzle solving.[Oh, and this isn't a walking simulator. It's certainly a puzzle game (too). Gone Home has a better story but zero puzzle solving. It has some things in common with AntiChamber, and almost nothing in common with Stanley Parable]

content:
Posted: December 14, 2015
												MIND: Path to Thalamus is a narrative puzzle experience.Design & ArtThe most obvious strongpoint of this game is its design and art. When I first played the game, it really drew me in instantly. I have never seen more beautifully crafted worlds and places in any game I played. Fitting color palettes, light and ethereal music support the visuals of the game positively.ControlsThe controls are pretty straightforward; if you played any shooter in the last century, you’ll have no problems whatsoever. You play from First-Person-perspective.Sound & MusicSounddesign is well managed and fitting. The music supports the game, feels well placed in concordance with most of the visuals and enhanced the gameplay.GameplayThe puzzles (which are the fundamental basis of this game) are forgiving enough at the beginning and get procedurally harder during the game. You can solve them with pure wit, sometimes you need trial and error (which, in my opinion, is rather a last resort than a viable solution to a problem). I have to note that most of the puzzles also require a LOT of walking. Solving a puzzle for the first time will take some duration and tenacity, since there is no running option in the game.WeakpointsThe game seems rather simplistic in its design and gameplay which positively supports the game, but that same simplicity also mortifies “Path to Thalamus”.The narrative part of the game is a very interesting topic (human psychology of loss and grief), yet its execution feels shallow and amiss. During the game, you rather scrape than plunge into said topics. The narrative picks you up at the beginning, but loses itself during later parts of the game. The voice acting feels cringeworthy at times and didn’t make me feel immersed enough. I guess the common disliking of the narrative part of the game lead to its near complete removal of the story in the “enhanced version” of the game (it is optional now, you don’t need to listen to the story). One of its weakpoints is fairly common among story-driven games: Replayability is completely out of the question, just like in Frictional Games’ “Amnesia” and “Penumbra”-series.And speaking of the devil, the “enhanced version” of the game (which was introduced recently) is the biggest thorn in my side. Holy hell. I bought and played the game before the new version and liked it to a certain degree. The “enhanced version” really ruined it for me. The game now runs more badly than before, I get way less Fps than before on the same settings, yet my hardware hasn’t changed. My PC fulfills all of the recommended settings. Not only that. At the same time, the graphics are now worse than before! How could this happen? The game is now more colorful than before, contrasts are higher (to a degree in which I couldn’t even see in the darkness, where before I could), my native resolution is now not supported by standard (What the frick?!), handling of objects feels worse and the ending and certain puzzles have been completely reworked.Concluding ThoughtsI really enjoyed the journey through someones elses mind. I can toss aside bad storylines by simply ignoring them. If you are a person, who enjoys beautifully crafted worlds and light puzzle solving, I urge you to get this game and install the old version of it (game options under steam -> betas -> old_mind). I cannot and will not support the new version of the game, since it feels worse than the unenhanced version. Don’t let yourself get fooled by this game's looks, while being beautiful, its narrative feels unstructured and messy. A real shame, because I want to love the game on both of these aspects. Yet I still enjoyed the game to a certain degree. Enjoy with caution. Do not play the new version if you want a decent experience with the game.

												Story:This is game about a guy in coma suffering from guilt. He wanders a surreal place in search of the thalamus reminding me of Dali, Myst or Inception at times. Gameplay:You walk at a rather slow pace through a pretty landscape and solve easy-medium puzzles (never took me more than 15 minutes on one) where you basically drop balls on switches that change day to night or sun to rain and so on. Some balls only appear at night, some bridges can only be crossed by rain and balls roll down when placed on a slope etc.I estimate the game takes around three hours to finish.Execution:The visual presentation looks gorgeous though in detail the foliage on the trees is somewhat flat. Piano music is serene and fits very well. Script and voiceover have been criticised by others - I think it's decent, he's in coma after all. The puzzle elements and the surreal setting sets the game appart from simple walking simulators like "Dear Esther" (which bored me terribly). Can recommend to friends of casual ambient puzzle games.

content:
Posted: April 23
												Aesthetically, this is a superb game - the visuals and the OST are astonishingly outstanding. In fact, the MIND world was so immersive, I wouldn't mind if it were a pure walking simulator with no actual gameplay at all, because what the environment and the atmosphere of the game delivered had already exceeded my expectation and impressed me thoroughly. It's so beautifully crafted that it can potentially relieve stress and anxiety, just as it did for me. Imagine walking on a vast meadow along a clear stream, listening to the sound of pouring rain, accompanied by the gentle thunder every now and then...nothing beats this kind of feelings my friend.However, if I have to comment on the gameplay, I would say, it's far less satisfying as the aesthetics. After all, this is mostly a puzzle game, whose genre relies heavily on level design and mechanics, but sadly, it falls short on these very aspects in my opinion. The levels feel like kind of a mess - some are very short, just go through a couple of portals and you're done, while some are fairly challenging, you might need to figure out a specific sequence of actions and time your moves as well. Normally, you would expect the difficulty and the length of a level to gradually increase, instead of being random or taking leaps, but in MIND, the pacing does feel a little bit off. As for the mechanics, they're interesting and quite esay to grasp. The problem is, there're only 4 main types of puzzles throughout the 4-5 hours of experience, which could get a bit repetitive as you progress further, and there's not much of out-of-the-box thinking involved, besides following the rules and control your timing. Overall, the gameplay is alright, it's just not that impressive. When it comes to the story, I don't have much to say - you'll find fragments of memories or thoughts of the main character in the game which slowly unveil the whole plot. In short, the story follows the protagonist's journey through his uncousious mind and his inner struggle of finding peace and forgiveness which awakes him from his coma and brings him back to his counsiousness. There're also some technical issues I want to point out. First of all, it's the optimization. My PC has no problem running other much more system demanding games but it gets a low general fps on this one and some frame drops from time to time. Another one is the subtitles, some disappear too quickly, some have no spacings, and there're also some being complete nonsense. It doesn't affect the experience but it wouldn't hurt fixing them right? I also found a bug in one of the extra Halloween levels, in which an element needed for solving the puzzle kept dispawning, making it impossible to progress, and eventually I gave up trying.That's all I have to say about MIND: Path to Thalamus. Despite its flaws, I did enjoy it and I recommend it to those who care for an atmospheric, light-hearted experience.

Posted: September 3, 2016
												This was a neat, if fairly pretentious, puzzle game.The puzzles themselves were somewhat clever, and I enjoyed the environments. I didn't encounter too many bugs, although I did manage to get myself stuck one time behind a portal with no way to finish a level because I had moved one of the "night" balls to the wrong spot and accidentally got it killed with no way to get it back. I was able to restart the level from the menu, however, and that cleared it up.One minor complaint is that the first proper level of the game is not entirely intuitive in that the mechanics of how things work and what you're to do are never explained, so it does take a bit of futzing around before you figure out that you're supposed to drop those balls inside the tree ring to progress.My biggest complaint is, I suppose, the writing and voice-over work. The dialog is that of a super-bitter cynic, and it starts to grate fairly quickly.That said, I'd definitely recommend this both for the visual presentation and the puzzle aspects. Once you get into the mindset of how the puzzle mechanics work, things start moving along at a pleasant pace. If you can ignore the pretentiousness of the narrator and his babbling about the tree of Thalamus, you'll have a pretty good time.Recommended: 4 out of 5.

Product received for free
												MIND: Path To Thalamus feels rather deep at times. It dares to reach out and touch you on an emotional level with brutal honesty and harsh realism. And even long after you’ve walked away from the screen, the experience resonates within you. By living through a single man’s never-ending nightmare, you learn that the path to redemption lies not in walking backwards through a path covered with eggshells, but in looking inward. So if you’re longing for a mind-bending experience that gets you to think outside of the box, Mind: Path to Thalamus is the game for you.Full review here: http://indiegamemag.com/mind-path-to-thalamus-review-dark-surrealism-and-epic-fantasy/

												Gameplay (7/10)This game has really well done puzzles. You have a relatively small set of game mechanics, combining them in creative ways to get through the next gate. This makes it similar in spirit to Portal's design, minus the dexterity. Puzzles tend not to be all that difficult, but are set up in such a way to be solved by honestly figuring them out and not by the frustrating trial and error that plagues many similar games.Story (3/10)The story is told through periodic monologues with a heavy dose of melodrama. It never really feels like it connects with the game itself until the end, which hits very suddenly and awkwardly. This isn't really a game to play for the story.Graphics/Sound (6/10)The environments look pretty cool, especially from a distance, but don't tend to hold up on closer inspection. The sound is serviceable.Overall Impression (6/10)Recommended, but with reservation and only for fans of puzzle games.

												First and foremost this game is a surreal experience. Secondly, it's a puzzle game.The puzzles are self-contained and you must solve each one to move on to the next, in a completely linear manner. Most are fairly straight forward and solving each overall puzzle isn't as satisfying as it should be. Instead, every few puzzles you will need to identify a new mechanic, and finding these are what make the experience rewarding. These are your eureka moments.As other comments have said, the story is way in the background somewhere and I wasn't engaged enough to look forward to the conclusion: I just wanted to solve each of the puzzles and see what came next. To unravel the story you don't need to do anything special. Even if you miss some of the sound bites, which can be found scattered around in some of the puzzles yet most of them right in your path, you will understand just fine what's going on.The length is quite short but fitting at 4-5 hours, and there is enough diversity to keep you interested until the end. For VR (I don't have a VR headset); given the limited selection of games right now, limited controls and the surreal landscapes, as well as the price and length; If you like puzzles this is one you should probably consider.

content:
Posted: June 25, 2015
												Positives:-Your first look at an area is quite pretty-Some inventiveness with respect to the puzzlesNegatives:-An entire area will have a single uniform look-Slow walking speed, large spaces-Basic puzzle format is "put ball A in slot B"-Awful story and voice acting-Wonky collision detectionNow, there *is* a certain amount of variation in the puzzles. Occasionally, you'll need to roll a ball down a hill so that it'll enter a slot after a certain delay, giving you time to get past an obstacle. At other times, you'll need to consider the interaction between the different effects slots have on the world--putting a ball in slot 1 will get you a second ball to put in slot 2, but it'll also raise a barrier; removing the ball from slot 1 again will remove the barrier, but also make the ball in slot 2 disappear. That sort of thing. There are a handful of interesting puzzles in the game. Unfortunately, there's a tremendous amount of tedious trudging you need to go through to get to these puzzles, and the world just doesn't sustain interest long enough to justify that. The environments are pretty enough, but really only when you first see them, because there's no variation within the environments to give you a sense of progress, apart from the various ball-and-slot macguffins scattered around. What seems initially like a lovely hilly meadow quickly becomes the frustratingly enormous meadow where you keep getting stuck on tiny bumps in the terrain, which makes you drop the ferschlugginger ball again. Dropping the ball is a pretty major issue in this game. It's really easy to accidentally lose your grip on a ball. You don't lose much progress when this happens (if any), but it gets tiresome quickly. You'll drop the ball when it gets caught on terrain, and you'll also drop the ball when you run into one of the myriad invisible walls. This is particularly frustrating, since you pick up the ball by walking into it, so if you walk into an invisible wall and that makes it drop, it drops right next to the wall, so when you walk into it again to try to pick it up, you'll often just walk straight into the invisible wall again and drop the stupid thing. Having your puzzle-solving interrupted with sessions just wrestling the collision detection is not fun.The game also insists on bludgeoning you with a terrible story. The plot, and I'm not making this up, runs like this: Father is a storm chaser. He takes the protagonist and his sister Sophia with him to pursue storms; Sophia drowns in a tsunami as a result. Protagonist never forgives his father for this, and expresses this by...becoming a storm chaser, and naming his own daughter Sophia. I think that's enough right there to give you a sense of the quality of the writing involved. It does not improve.Definitely not recommended, unless you thought Dear Esther's story was terrific, but needed puzzles, and also thought the best puzzles in Portal 2 were the ones designed by Wheatley.

content:
Posted: September 4, 2015
												Mind: Path to Thalamus was worth playing for picturesqueness alone.... but I don't expect others to share that sentiment. The puzzles didn't take much thought at all, (except in the final area, but even then it was primarily "use logic to put steps in order across a large space") and were definitely not the focus of the game. Sometimes they were frustrating because they were unclear. Sometimes they were frustrating because they took more work executing than figuring out. Sometimes they were about running everywhere in a huge map hunting for something, and next trying to find your way back in dense fog. Sometimes they were about putting something somewhere and then running to another location before you run out of time. That being said, the puzzle elements do some really amazing meshing with the graphics/atmosphere, and other games could stand to learn from Mind:PathToThalamus's clever designs in that regard. To spend more time harping on the graphics: Of the fourteen-or-so locations, I have vivid recollections of every one. the variety was staggering, and my favor ranges from merely "pretty" to "some of the most gorgeous landscapes I have ever been in in a game." I was able to run it decently on an older computer as well. The pacing in the game was alright, but the random difficulty spikes were not welcome, and didn't add enough to the game to justify themselves. Neither was the plot worth including. Honestly, the plot managed to detract from the game more than it added, and I don't think that I am being unfair. I found it amusing at times, nicely mellow at others, but overall bland and distracting from the other parts which the games does far better. Some people find it overly obtuse and annoyingly philosophical. Others find it obnoxious, hollow inside, with nothing really to say except to try and be clever for lack of something better to do. The developers listened to the public and adjusted the script since I played it. I liked the game enough to try and replay it to see what they had fixed, but the game crashed repeatedly (.... ..... .... ...) in one area, so I wasn't able to get past it to appreciate their upgrades. They can't have really fixed the plot drastically, unfortunately. I know so because: 1) it lacked depth to begin with 2) they were removing dialogue, not adding last I heard 3) some critical parts of the game depend on whatever remains of the plot they started with.So yeah. Play it for the graphics, atmosphere, imagination, and vastness of scale. Love it for that. Enjoy witnessing the (limited) way you can change the world, but don't expect to interact much mechanics-wise or mind-wise.Similar games: NaissanceE, (similar in puzzle worth, similar in atmosphere impact, similar in plot worth, more platforming difficulty, different surrealism style) Kairo, (slightly better puzzles, worse graphics, different surrealism style) The Path (slightly better plot but more "poetic," worse graphics, lack of puzzles)Better games: Dear Esther (lack of puzzles, better plot, similar striking environments worth, stronger atmosphere, deeper meaning/experience)Journey (better/less puzzles, better plot, similar striking environments worth, stronger atmosphere, deeper meaning/experience)The Void (Extremely tough mechanics to master, slightly worse visuals, stronger atmosphere, deeper meaning/experience, less fun (a lot less fun) )

												Uh, meh, mixed feelings on this one. The graphics are gorgeous, love the skyboxes, wide landscapes and emptiness of the world. The puzzles are often, even in its short playtime, extremely frustrating and require way too much walking around aimlessly wishing you could move quicker and just trying random configurations until it works. It was like they tried to make something very deep and metaphoric half of the time, and just said ♥♥♥♥ it the other half, making it feel very disjointed and pretentious. And ugh... the voiceovers... Especially at the end the voiceovers ruin any sense of immersion into the story with a seemingly bombastic "boss fight" that tries oh so hard to be epic but just made me sit in wonder what the hell they tried to do. The vague and unconvincing narrative makes it very difficult to get immersed with the character. Never have I actually felt "sorry" the problems he faces. The ending is apparently supposed to explain that the game is satirical to other "pretentious" games like Portal that also have very vague narrative, but it's done very unconvincingly: Nowhere else is this sentiment obvious than some voice overs there, making it almost seem like the developers realized how weak some of their writing was that they decided a day before release to just call it satire, giving it a real "holier than thou" feel.Buy it if you love weird, curious environments and great graphics, and can put up with sometimes frustrating puzzles and mediocre narrative or if you are a game designer (it does some interesting things you can learn from), otherwise I can't really recommend it.I'm feeling a light 6

Posted: September 14, 2015
												Imagine an angsty 20-something, in love with Stephen King and Silent Hill, writing a story that he thinks is sooo cool and philosophical about loss, obsession and finding himself. Then trying to turn it into a mix of Dear Esther, Myst and a bit of Penumbra: Requiem while having some good ideas and some fantastically looking levels. Then add some nice music and absolutely horrendous voice acting that makes some free horror flash games sound amazing. And you get Mind: Path to Thalamus.It does look unbelievably great and some of it's puzzles are actually good and smart. But, at the same time, a lot of puzzles are either boring, or frustrating or just "really?!" and there's no real motivation to keep going. There is a story happening, but given the horribleness of the script and the acting with which it is read, it's hard to care. Especially, when game suddenly decides that it needs a "boss" which works in a rather bs way or just drops you in an almost zero visibility expansive area and expects you to care to find the way.So - visuals are great, some music is very good, but everything else usually ranges from "why do I care" to "no, seriously, why do I even bother playing this?!".

												Normally, this kind of game drives me wild. I love these strange, artistic, narrative explorations but I have to be honest and say, for me, Mind: Path to Thalamus was disappointing.I found myself constantly comparing Mind to Dream, another game along similar lines, and in comparison I found Mind wanting. The voice acting is poor, the story is bland and contrite, and the puzzles are largely trial-and-error.Something that annoyed me was the evil-looking red shadow people, which we're led to believe are personifications of something dark within the protagonists mind, likely trauma from the events which unfold.This is one of those moments where Dream shines; Dream shows the darker elements of the protagonists psyche with symbolic and clever imagery, all based on dream theory. Things like mannequins and mazes, things with meaning.In Mind, however, the shadow people are just cut-and-paste representations of blanket "darkness" or "evil".In short, I feel that, so far, Mind is a real let-down, which is a shame because it has buckets of potential and some really stunning environments.To summarise, Mind is a game designed by a team of artists. Dream is a game designed by a varied team, and the end result shows great superiority to this.

content:
Posted: July 2, 2016
												MIND: Path to Thalamus might be described as a "Walking simulator" type game, but I'd place it more in the "Puzzle Platformer" genre; that's fine, not exactly what I was expecting, but still a style that I enjoy. The problem is that it doesn't do much with either element of that genre: barely any platforming, and the puzzles--for the most part--aren't very puzzling.The game manages to have beatiful environments, that you can't explore, and a nice ambient soundtrack, that you don't hear often. This kind of makes sense within the constraints of the plot, because (SPOILER that's given away by the title anyway): you're withing the main character's mind. I'm not sure about most people, but I don't hear music 24/7 in my brain; the invisible walls with lush scenery is still irksome--I'm not free to visit all the beauty that I see behind these narrow walls, and paths so obvious they could almost be described as "on rails."By far the most egregious transgression of the game, though, is the narration. The story is actually quite interesting: it has good character development, wonderful visual representations of the plot (all the visual metaphors and motifs are excellent), and an intriguing concept (representing the subconscious mind of the character). The narration ruins all of this; the exposition is helpful, but felt rushed at the end cutscene (as if not enough had come through during the game) and most of it was telling the audience how to interpret the gameplay or cutscenes as part of the plot instead of just letting us make those connections.If this was a free game that I played on some website while I was bored, I could forgive it and say that it's worth a play as a kind of timewaster. On steam for $9, I can't in good conscience recommend it to others and say that it's a good investment. I see a lot of potential in the devs and want them to receive the support, both financially and motivationally, to continue honing their skill, but I'd rather fund a new game than misdirect people to support them through this one.

												From the outside, everything about this game looks gorgeous. The scenery is breathe taking and the trailing... "How many times will I kill her?" I was hooked right off the bat with that one powerful yet intriguing sentence. The game starts extremely strong too; the opening scene is up there alongside Half Life 2 or Portal 2 when it comes to catching your attention.After that, it all breaks down. The puzzle system, which is the core of the game, isn't really flawed itself. It may not be introduced the best way possible, but it still is a decent and original idea, and the mechanics are well explored throughout the game. What bugged me the most is how slow and tiring solving the puzzles felt. Yes, the vast and exquisit landscape is awesome, but having to walk across it back and forth trying to solve a puzzle is not fun. Most of the time, you know exactly what you need to do, but doing it is just 10 minutes of straight walking, with no music or narration to keep you occupied. I do enjoy just looking around, but at some point, even that doesn't do it anymore.The narration is also another aspect they would've benefited greatly to have stepped up on.Overall, the game had a lot of potential, but it fell short in a few key parts, which ruined the whole thing.

content:
Posted: March 22
												OK. I'm only like 1 hour into the game, aaannnnddd... sense is not being made. I walked into a tunnel with water and got stuck. Literally, I fell into some kind of hole half way between two levels of the tunnel and couldn't get out. So I went to the menu to see if I could restart that section/chapter, but I selected a chapter I hadn't seen yet/before. I was under water(?) but couldn't move or anything so I started mashing all the keys on the keyboard and ...stuff happened. Gonna see if I can completely start over tomorrow and see where that gets me. Oh. I already earned achievements; for what I have no idea.Gonna give this a thumbs up only because I have to give it something and I'm not far enough along to definitively dislike it.PS. I bought the game because of the music in the trailer.-----UPDATE-----So, I finished the game. More or less. I think I might have skipped some of it, but I can't tell because of the interface issues. I don't recommend this game for the following reasons:1. It makes less than no sense. No rhyme. No reason. Although the puzzles are interesting and many are challenging, apparently you don't have to complete them. Like, any of them.2.  There's no reason for the game not to launch in fullscreen mode. I had to find a discussion thread to find out how (Alt+Enter).3. You can't tell what "Chapter" you are in at any given time. If you pause the game (bring up the menu), I saw no indication of my current progress/position in the narative. Pressing "PLAY" returns you to the beginning of the chapter you are in.4. There's no cursor/reticle so you're just guessing if you have a tumbleweed within your grasp or not, and the tumbleweeds are the *only* thing you can interact with in the game.5. They introduce game mechanics in a bad way. I skipped one chapter because I couldn't figure out the puzzle's mechanics or what to do, but in a later(?) chapter the mechanic became obvious.6. The subtitles are too freaking small, out of sync, and sometimes jumbled and unreadable.7. I spent at least a quarter (if not a third) of my time in the game staring at a blank screen wondering if the game had crashed.8. I encountered very little music. Although, I must say I actually bought the game because of the music in the trailer, and when/where that music appears in the game I found very affecting.After a few hours it became obvious I was traipsing through some shmuck's inner psychological problems. Personally, I found that irritating. But that's just me. So I don't hold it against the game. What I do hold against the game is that I just didn't care about anything. I had no motivation to complete any puzzle, and completing a puzzle didn't give any reward I could discern.I bought the game at 75% off for $2.24. Essentially I bought it for that one piece of music. Don't buy this game if you're looking for some kind of story to motivate you and tie everything together. There isn't some great revelation at the end where "everything suddenly makes sense."Interesting puzles/mechanics. Poor execution. 1 awesome song.

'game' (if you can call it one) was worth releasing in such a state.Yes, several other users have mentioned that there is a narrative of sorts. But for now... it feels more like a proof of concept than something I've call a real game.

												I played through the first four areas and only for a short time.  By the fourth area, I did not find the game to be engaging.The story is of some guy who loses his sister and daughter, and copes with their loss by way of a series of esoteric imagery puzzles.  Of the puzzles I played, they were very simple, and not challenging, and most egregiously, relied on the player to guess the solutions. I got a jittery and inconsistent fps (mid-20's) on the low settings.  For context, my hardware is not that great, but I've seen better preformance on more hardware intensive programs.  Your milage my vary.The controls were sluggish.  This may possibly be related to the above.  A grabbed object moved at a different rate than the camera did, creating a naseating and disoreinting experience.In summary, I did not like this game.  I thinkn it may be intended for a totally different audience than average PC gamers (note that this game has VR support).

												I got about 45 minutes into this game and had to stop. I can't really say much about the narrative beacuse as of yet I feel like I've learnt nothing and I feel no connection to the protagonist and his daughter whatsoever. My main fault is with the gameplay itself. So far the puzzles have been annoying rather than challenging, forcing you to search a large area (at a painfully slow pace due to the lack of a sprint option) in order to find a ball or where to place it. This, added to the artistic/abstract way in which they're presented makes the puzzles longer but no more enjoyable. Either that or challenging for all the wrong reasons. I just found them entirely tedious.Another thing was the size of the area you were allowed to roam in - it is much larger than you need in some places but with no reward for exploring that I've seen so far. This is made all the more irritating by the slow pace at which you're forced to travel. There's no interesting information, just more views. The visuals are stunning I do admit, to the point where I have screenshots in amongst my computer backgrounds. However I was expecting more of a relaxed atmosphere - there were several points when I just felt kinda creeped out :PAll in all based on what I've seen I wouldn't get this again - and I essentially paid pennies for this in a Humble Bundle. Though I will try to play on and will edit this review if I ever complete the game as the many positive reviews give me hope that it might pick up.

content:
Posted: December 29, 2014
												This is an uncommonly gorgeous game - the art direction is fantastic.  The sheer scale of some of the things that happen in this game is breathtaking.  (Visually, this might be the best use of the Unreal engine I've ever seen.)  Without being too specific about the puzzles, once you figure out that backtracking is a thing, they strike a decent balance between fair and challenging - they're mostly fun and totally solvable if sometimes a bit cryptic.  The narrator is a prick - but I think that's part of the point.  He's a deeply flawed guy - and while the game's journey does represent a maturing process for him - he's still kind of a prick with loads of baggage.  It's as if he's searching too hard for meaning - calls himself out on it - and keeps doing it anyway.  If you can get past the imperfect character, the game is amazing - worth playing for the art direction and execution alone.  It may not be as polished as Portal 2 - but it's made by a much smaller team, and the artistic aspect of the game really knocks it out of the park.  If you like surrealism - this is for you.  Dive in, and get lost in another world.  8/10 highly recommended.

Posted: September 4, 2015
												Mind is a curious game. But also absolutely brutal at times with its puzzles. But due to it being so curious to play, you're driven forward by what you might see next.In terms of presentation, art-style and content it is fantastic. What it struggles with it leaving you wondering what you are supposed to do at times. It doesn't happen very often, but when it does you really end up being clueless for quite some time before you have those 'ah ha!' moments. That may be in part due to the surreal environments where doing one thing triggers something completely unexpected, so that detatchment of cause and expected effect in itself can be a hinderence. But at the same time, its like someone put you in an empty room filled with buttons and you've just got to push one after another to satisfy your curiousity.And that is what makes it hard to say if this is a good game or not. Replay value is absolutely zero, because once you've been through the game the driving force behind why you kept playing has been lost. But, it does a good job of keeping you playing... somehow.. it just does. Hypnotic, but in an intellectual way. Mind Candy rather than Eye-Candy.There's not many games I could even describe as Mind-Candy. So, yeah. Buy this and experience something quite unique. There is certainly not enough games which can claim to be genuinely unique these days.

content:
Posted: January 21, 2015
												Mind: Path to Thalamus is another entry into the narrative focused art games. This one struck me as having been highly influenced by Dear Esther (especially in the tone and pace of the narration, as well as some of the areas), coupled with a more puzzle-driven experience, not unlike Portal (its intent being completely different, though).Unfortunately, the writing was weak, in my opinion, and the game seems very incoherent in its quality. Some parts of the game were truly good, blending its audio-visual design very nicely with the puzzles, while others just fell flat on their face, with far more generic looks, and puzzles whose pieces were simply hidden, leading to a frustrating experience.PresentationThe first thing that strikes you in M:PtT is its visual fidelity. It has high quality textures and shaders that are very well used, especially at the start of the game. The skyboxes are  majestic -- that's the best way to describe it, very detailed and often chaotic, in a good way  -- paired well with the lighting effects. It's just an awesome looking game, if you like wandering around and sightseeing. Doesn't quite hold itself the whole way throughThe only complaint I have with it is that, while the beach areas seem are brilliant, with a bit of classic architecture and nicely reflecting sand, some of the other areas are far blander. There was a cave almost identical to the one in Dear Esther (which is unfortunate, because it's certainly beautiful, despite losing the unique factor), and there are some cannyon-esque areas that are not that awe inducing.The plain areas are also very well done with their use of color and foliage, very cool! There are also some more other-wordly realms that look pretty good.The only technical problem with it was the popping that happened due to the low draw-distance with some objects, even with everything maxed.The sound design was also very much alike Dear Esther. It's mostly very quiet and relaxing, with the occasional piano piece, and calm narration. It's certainly very atmospheric, and while not particularly memorable, I think it helps  carrying the experience!I have a few problems with the writing. Presumably, it was too esoteric and pretentious when the game launched, so they've rewritten the script, making the story more clear. Unfortunately, they've completely removed the old script, as it seems. I wanted to try it out for myself, but I don't think that's possible. What's left, is a perhaps too direct and concrete script about the story of the game. So concrete that it lacks identification with the player, unless you were in a similar situation... Which deals with running from a tornado. Not something many people have ever been involved with, I'd say!This is perhaps not 100% fair, as there are aspects with which one could identify himself, but they're also so prevalent nowadays that it's a bit tiresome (related to guilt and family issues).This story is given between the puzzles, during otherwise dead time. Since two of the characters share the same name (for story reasons) it can be a bit confusing at times to know who exactly the game's talking about, due to the fragmented exposition.Regardless, I don't think it's bad, just felt a bit underwhelming, taken the rest of the presentation. I think I would have liked to at least play through the original script.General MechanicsThe game's puzzles revolve around "manipulating weather". However, it's not as cool as it sounds, and it's only so metaphorically speaking. The main characters (from what I understood, a family tradition of sorts) studies weather phenomena. There's the connection.However, how the weather changes affect the game's mechanics is completely untied to actual weather, working just as a mechanic. With which there's nothing wrong, but it feels like the developer tried a bit too hard and in the end dropped the ball, for the most part.The puzzles are a mixture of conception and execution, the latter relying on the physics system, which is not very well explained at all.You have a neuro-something sphere, that you place in an element circle, to activate it. You can also stand on those circles yourself to activate said weather mechanic. You can control Fog, Day and Night, Rain, and Time. Night opens up portals, and something gives you a ball that only appears during the night, Rain rises platforms, Fog gives you access to small area (and propulsion -- where the physics come in), and Time reconstructs some buildings. -- Looking back at it, there's connection between the mechanics and the actual story, though very subtle.Generally, you wander around the levels, find the pieces, and then place the sphere and yourself sequentially, following a very linear path to the end of the level.It certainly sounds good in concept! And sometimes, they were nicely designed, on other times, not really. I'll now discuss the particular points that made this game frustrating, to me.1.Invisible and/or Artificial WallsThis is a big sore spot, to me. The game features these very fast, ever expanding areas that look absolutely amazing. There's also an almost perfect ballance between empty space and "landmarks" in some levels. However, once you try to go off the path, the game blocks you path with an invisible walls. On the first levels, this wasn't really an issue, as it seemed to give you quite a lot of freedom. later on, though, it revealed itself as something different.For such an atmospheric experience, letting the player wonder would be far for enjoyable -- perhaps having an improved Dear Esther influence, maybe even giving some of the more esoteric script passages to the player during those moments. The biggest issue with this, though, is how they place a single pillar or tree off in the distance, isolated from everything else. In any other game, this would be like a beacon, something for the player to investigate! Of course, once you walk 5 steps, you'll encounter an invisible wall. It feels so counter-intuitive... If there's to be a wall there, don't place those beacons. I mean, since so obvious that I'm not sure I'm missing some deep metaphor, here... Oh well. It could be much more by changing this simple aspect.2.Puzzles are most about finding the pieces than putting them togetherSounds cute, but what exactly do I mean. Aside from being very limiting, exploration-wise, the levels can be quite large -- which may sound contradictory, but stick with it.While somewhat large, they're very linear in where you can go. However, since the various pieces are so spread, every solution you might think of, will often take more time than it needed. Moreover, if it fails, you'll have to wander around for some more time, because it's not very clear, most of the time.For example, one puzzle was literally about taking the sphere and walking in a very defined path in front of you. You would finish the level in 10 seconds. However, that was only due to its initial conditions. If you took the sphere and went somewhere else, you would break those conditions. I felt rather lost, to be honest. The problem with that level was that you could not see the consequences of your actions. This happens more than once.This is very frustrating. You could solve the puzzles by pure luck quickly -- otherwise, you'd have to rely on guesswork and trial and error.ConclusionEnough rambling. I think I've written about my biggest problems with Mind: Path to Thalamus.It's a very beautiful game, and the first level really impressed me, even from a puzzle standpoint. Unfortunately, the rest of the game doesn't seem to have as much work and polish put into it, and ends up having some very frustrating puzzles, hurting the rest of the experience a lot.

												3 minutes into the game I encountered a crash.  After restarting and "adjusting" things I played the game for several hours.  When I say "played" I mean I walked.  To the game's credit the art direction is very nice.  The story is lacking and attempts to be elevated by being "in the mind", but is mostly drawn out.  The graphics are not actually that impressive which is covered up by bloom.  To the game's credit it does have puzzles, but all the puzzles are walk into mirror, move a ball somewhere or just walk forward.  Apparently walk forward is in fact a puzzle. I did not actually complete the game because on one of the later puzzles the ball I needed glitched out during a fateful teleporter incident.  There is no "restart puzzle" (can't put enough quotes around puzzle) option so the game expected me to redo an entire chapter.  I know there are people who will play games purely based on concept and art direction; this is the game for them.  For people who want something more than a first person game with a collection of bugs I'd look else where.

After walking down wide white hallways with hanging paintings and finished floors you get to an Oculus Rift. "Try it!" they insist.You put it on. You walk around this linear path for awhile. You don't need explosions and guns to entertain you, and you certainly don't need a tutorial to hit you over the head, but this world seems pointless and empty. You keep walking around in the virtual world so as to not disappoint your date. After enough ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥tting, you take off the headset."So? What'd ya think? Pretty cool, RIGHT?" they say all proud of themselves."It was. Interesting," you say.You indugle in the wine at the gallery to try to make the best of your time while your artist date drones on and on about the state of art today with other artists and connoisseurs. You're drunk and bored so you just stare at the enormous  statue in the middle of the room that you swear looks like a woman ♥♥♥♥ing a dog, yet everyone insists is abstract art. You say goodnight and don't ♥♥♥♥ them because you don't want to have to sit through another date with that person.

												Playing this game is the equivalent of dating a gorgeous airhead.  I'm intrigued by its visual beauty but trying to find meaning or interest in the shallow wastelands of this looker's mental landscape is a chore. I turned it off early so I wouldn't spoil my experience by seeing too much.  But in the end I should have watched the rest and exposed myself to the simple yet often-times obtuse puzzle system and saved myself a few bucks.  If you’re interested in MIND I’d suggest you just watch a YouTube playthrough like I'm about to do.Dangit, I really wanted to like this one too...
