number of helpful: 25 of 57 people (44%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: August 5, 2014
												(Update!) While I have to credit these fellas for making changes and listening to us, I am still unable to sell this to you. YET, FOLLOW THESE BOYS! THEY HAVE LEARNED FROM THEIR MISTAKES AND NEED SOME SUPPORT! Unlike most developers out there, once they are wrong they give up! This is not the case here and to be honest... I want to give it a thumbs up, but I paid for the original release and that is what the following review is based upon. Enjoy, your life. Now before we get started, I know a lot of you here are going to buy this regardless of what I write and while you shell out your cash, you will probably be thinking that I just don't get it. That is not at all correct, I spend most of my time on puzzle and/or story driven games. This is a product aimed at those of us that love surrealism and storytelling, but don't let that be the only reason you want to spend hard earned cash on it. I for one love anything that gets me thinking or asking questions. Sadly, this game had me asking all the wrong questions and came across as an ego trip.I don't want to be only negative, so I will point out that this game is not hard on the eyes when the screen is not tearing from time to time. Also, the music when playing is decent, it just always seems to fade away or get cut off before being allowed to really go anywhere amazing. Now let me get to why I am not able to recommend this product. It has a lot to do with the poor writing being about as good as the voice acting and the game design making you wonder, 'was that a bug?' For example, in the prologue I came to a point where the puzzle had me wondering, was that even suppose to happen? I do understand this was intended to be a cool little illusion type puzzle, but it seems sloppy and lazy. For some reason, the game makers think having you use reflections to find your way is fun. Followed by some trial and error puzzles that involve placing things in the right areas, that quickly become more of a chore than entertainment. By now you might be thinking, 'If I smoke some bud it has to be cool, right?' WRONG! If anything, you are going to find yourself cheesed out by the terrible writing that has such a hard on for itself. The screen tearing really is ugly when it does happen, it's not a lot but it does like to pop up; just could have been avoided all together. There is too much walking from one point to the next making any back~tracking that much more painful. The bad design has the game come across as rushed and broken when really these choices are on purpose in order to throw you off. The story is pretencious, with the main character going on and on about himself. The amount of times I heard the players character mention his daughters name in the first few minutes became annoying and way over written. It seems as if the developers made this in a bedroom, while the voice actor sounds as if he just wants to go home. I would be more kind if this game was not so full of pretentious bull$hit. The writer seems to be patting himself on the back the entire game, forcing words into the script out of nowhere as if he just learned them and wants to show off. The worlds seem forced, as if trying to be strange instead of mind~blowing or awe~inspiring. We have seen this all before and I don't see why there is any reason to choose this over some of the other 3D puzzle games on the market. I came across a lot of invisible walls, something I thought no longer existed in games these days. After awhile I just stopped trying to explore the worlds, since I was always stopped, keeping me stuck walking across fields knowing that it looks open, but is really linear.I understand this is suppose to be art and that I should have an open mind, (which I do) yet if that is how you want to look at it, then the art here is far too self indulged, closing your mind and making you see what the developers want you to see. The price is not so steep that I feel robbed completely, still I did pay enough to where I am let down by the product. If it was written better and the voice actor for the main character was not so off, I could put up with the level design and other problems. Everytime I hear the main voice actor speak about his daughter, all I can think to myself is how he does not sound at all like a strom chaser/father, and instead a game developer who really wants you to admire his work. It also comes across as if he is reading his lines right off a piece of paper for the first time. I really hate to give this a thumbs down since it could have been something, yet there are other games out there better than this. If you really must play something new and have yet to enjoy, A Story About My Uncle, then try that first. It is far better than this on all levels and if you need more surreal worlds and 3D puzzles, then maybe this is for you, just get ready for a character that loves to hear his own voice. I'll end this review with a quote from the game."All this sounds pretty cheesy and lame, I'm sure. And it is."

												Visually very pretty first-person puzzle game that attempts to tell a deeply emotional story and falls flat on its face in the process. There's no denying the technical prowess on display here, but both gameplay and story leave a lot to be desired.Puzzles start up promisingly and introduce a couple of nice mechanics but then get stuck in a rut, rehashing the same few elements over and over again for the rest of the game. You'll be hauling tumbleweed balls (that inconveniently block a huge chunk of your vision) made out of synapses until the cows come home, or rather until the pretentious story finally reaches its disappointing conclusion.Annoying voice acting and story, puzzles that frequently require hefty doses of trial-and-error and some extremely dubious gameplay elements (ultra-thick fog, anyone?) really made this one a drag. I was hoping it'd get better towards the end, but it actually got worse.

												Mind: Path to Thalamus is a contemplative first-person puzzle game about loss and guilt. Set in a truly breathtaking dream-world, the main gameplay features are some light platforming and puzzle-solving.The puzzles are not very challenging, taking a little time to figure out the first time, but mostly just there to drive you through the narrative as well as making you explore in the beautiful world.The biggest criticism of the game at release was the voice-over narration which just felt distracting and annoying with its near-constant presence. However this was later toned down quite a bit, but the ending part still has an extremely annoying voice-over that just runs on repeat and completely destroys the mood of the game.The game seems very well optimized and runs perfectly fine on my 5 year old machine with a GTX580 card.Apart from its minor flaws, I really recommend this game for fans of slow-paced contemplative games.

content:
Posted: January 6, 2015
												As a game and an interactive experience, Mind: Path to Thalamus succeeds in being one of the more successful attempts to bring logical puzzle play to a surreal environment. As a metaphorical narrative, it leaves something to be desired.The game play of Mind is simple, in order to proceed you have to bring these blue tumbleweed things to various locations in order to manipulate the environmental aspects of day/night, weather, and time in order to unlock the path forward. Utilizing a gradual learning curve that still offers a challenge, Mind starts you off with one element at a time - for instance: teaching you that sometimes an object you need may be visible only at night and then having you figure out how to acquire this object without sacrificing some other aspect of your progression - before introducing multiple elements at once By the end of the game you're very much thinking 4th dimensionally about things, but even the head-scratchingest of puzzles were logical in the end. Even at my most frustrated, I never thought "that's a stupid solution" and instead was more apt to berate myself for not having noticed it sooner.More than just eye candy. Mind utilizes its surreal environments to full effect, with puzzles involving everything from reflections to portals, and gravity. Sadly however the story seems virtually divorced from the game play aside from the its heavy handed ending levels. Unlike Papo & Yo (another surreal adventure puzzler) Mind says too much too often and relies too much on narration and all-too-obvious symbols to achieve its metaphor. The gameplay could easily be read as part of the main character's coma-induced journey, but it rarely relates directly to the subjects and experiences the narrator talks about. Add to this the fairly amateur voice acting and VERY uneven dialogue volume (with no option to adjust) and Mind's narrative experience fell a little flat with me, feeling extraneous at best and pretentious at worst.Overall the game was an enjoyable experience however and for the environments and puzzles alone is worth checking out. There are some interesting ideas at work here that I felt justified my time spent with the game.

												I've got to be honest - I put off playing this game for a while due to some negative reviews on community boards, but I finally broke down and decided to buy it and give it a shot for myself... and I am actually REALLY glad that I did. The game is downright gorgeous. It runs well even on my Intel HD Graphics Card laptop. The puzzles are actually simple in design, but complex to solve at times, which is a great balance. While the mechanics themselves are simple, it's the order of the puzzles which provides the challenge - it requires you to actually use your brain! The story was pleasing, and I actually found myself emotionally effected at times, be it fear, sadness, awe, terror or joy. Few games can cycle a player through those emotions, and Path to Thalamus did a fantastic job. My only criticism of this entire game is a repeat of what others have said, that at times the voice acting can be a little "dry". It's not that it was terrible, but there were many times that I just didn't fell immersed by the narration. IE: It wasn't believable. That said, it was not a bother at all, and without the voice overs, the game would have been less, so I am actually glad that they were there. All in all, if you are looking for a challenging yet relaxing game, with beautiful visuals, great music, a pretty well though-out story, and a satisfying conclusion, this is probably something you will enjoy. Definitely recommended.

Posted: June 28, 2015
Only play this game if you enjoy a series of decent puzzles and can overlook things like bad writing and dialogue.Mind: Path to Thalamus shines in its visuals and puzzle design.  I just wish they had applied the same amount of care and devotion to the story, writing, and dialogue.  Everything about the story feels like a very rough draft, written and recorded in one take on a lazy afternoon.  I can't help but wonder if the writer was trying to work through some of their own personal issues by shoe-horning them into this game.  It works well enough as a game.  A series of mechanics that a user must manipulate in order to reach the next level.  The puzzles are challenging and will consume a few hours of your evening.  But as an interactive story, it barely reaches mediocre.And the ending... god the ending. I won't spoil anything for you, but... maybe just shut the game off and uninstall it before the "final boss battle".  Yeah, an emotive story/puzzle game about coping with death ends with a stereotypical final boss battle.  If that doesn't clue you in to how disjointed the last chapter of this game feels, then I assure you your money is better spent elsewhere.  Reaching the final boss put me over the 2-hour limit to get a refund.  I'm going to request one anyway just to test the waters.Like I said, the puzzles are expertly crafted, and the maps are stunning to behold.  I found myself taking several screenshots throughout my play session.  For these reasons I do recommend the game.  But only with the caveat that everything else about the game felt like an afterthought.  I would suggest playing the game on mute, with the subtitles turned on.  Any voice you can conjure in your head will be miles ahead of the recorded dialogue in terms of quality and believability.

Intuitive, logical and very fun to play.

content:
Posted: June 8, 2015
												Mind is a pretty straighforward first person puzzle game.  There are only a handful of mechanics, but the puzzles increase in difficulty relatively smoothly as the game progresses.  I played this game hoping it would be similar to Myst, but it isn't.  Mind is very linear.  The logic involved isn't quite as engaging as Myst or Kairo, but you probably aren't going to get stuck due to a disconnect between how you think and how the developers want you to think.  The game boils down to find a ball, put the ball where it's supposed to be, advance to next puzzle.  A lot of people compare this game to Dear Esther.  That is a pretty fair comparison.  I would consider Mind to be 70% Dear Esther, 20% Kairo, and 10% Myst.Mind has a lot of very beautiful scenery and magnificent lighting.  Just looking around is a lot fun,  Unfortunately there are huge amounts of empty space that ultimately don't add much to the experience.  There is a desparate need for a sprint function.  Early on I would explore to see more of the environments, but you have to slowly wander back to where you were supposed to be.  At times, the only difficulty in progressing is trying to find the ball in a large environment.  Still, a lot of the environments are pretty cool, especially the ones that are more surreal.  It may sound kind of droll, but the game is still pretty engaging.  There's a somewhat decent story as you progress.  It's not too long, which I consider a plus because it doesn't overstay its welcome, and I never got stuck for significant time until the last main puzzle.Overall, Mind is pretty simple but incredibly polished.  I love the small details, like rolling the ball if you hold it close to the ground as you move, or the effect of light shining through the ball's holes when you hold it up to a light source.  I would recommend playing it if you're looking for an artsy eyecandy game with semi-casual puzzle elements.

content:
Posted: December 21, 2014
												It's amazing to me that a game so beautiful in its design and creative in its puzzles can be so deeply marred by the writing and voice acting. Earlier on in the game, I had dismissed the comments in reviews that detracted the voice acting, thinking "it's not so bad". But now, having finally finished the game, I understand. While I think the story itself is very interesting, the way it is told and not shown ruins the execution. The narration seems to assume that the player is not clever enough to understand what is going on unless it is painstakingly explained by way of pretentious voice-acting. At times, it even seems to be self-deprecating, as if aware of some of its own flaws. The ending is particularly guilty of this, which very nearly robs the player of any satisfaction to be found in the resolution of the story. In particular, the comments about the "evil ball of death" and the voice-swapping were sheer moments of face-palm for me. So despite the fact that I found this game incredible on several other levels, it left me on a sour note. Am I implying I could have done a better job with the writing? Absolutely not, and I have to stress that I commend the creators of this game for such an excellent story and concept. I just feel that the game would have nothing to lose and everything to gain by simply removing the narration entirely. Perhaps this could even be a settings option to just disable it. For bonus points, the game could "show" a bit more of the story along the way in place of telling it. Now that my complaints are out of the way, I can get on to writing about what an amazing game this is, on every other level. Based on the concept, design, and gameplay, it could have been the ideal game for me. I was overjoyed to find a game based on the intersection of the exploration of consciousness and psychology with fantastical landscapes and locations - something like that is right up my alley. And indeed, that's what this is, and it's executed wonderfully. Many of the level designs, art concepts and effects that you'll experience here are truly stunning, and I found this to be even more true as I approached the end. While the puzzle mechanics could have used a bit more diversity, the different ways they are combined in the more challenging puzzles keeps things fresh and enjoyably mind-bending. The gameplay is at its most satisfying when it nudges you to think in new ways in order to solve different types of puzzles. And the locations are perpetually screenshot-worthy, always vast and mysterious, a joy to explore. Each of these elements are incredibly well-executed and provide a unique experience.I spent about 5 hours here and would gladly enjoy another playthrough someday. I don't feel the flaws in the game come close to eclipsing the things it does well, so I can only click the recommend button, and hope you enjoy this game with appropriately adjusted expectations for the narration.

												I have played many puzzle games at this point... and this one is definitely a fairly unique take on the genre.  At least where the "setting" is concerned.  Most of the puzzles started out pretty simple and I was beginning to fear that the game may just be too repetative and confusing, but it got better as I progressed further.  The puzzles near the end were definitely a bit more challenging.Potential Gameplay Spoiler:  There is one section of the game (the colossus) that is a bit more frustrating as it is less of a puzzle and more of a "dodge the giant foot about to step on you" level, but with the right technique it actually wans't as difficult as it appeared to be at first.  Hang in there and it gets better again.That said... It was indeed a weird game and I'm still not quite sure what I think about the storyline... it left me feeling a little bit uneasy at times but I suppose that was its intent.Overall I think this game was successful in entertaining me for a few hours, and for that I will give it a thumbs up!  Not much replay value though, and it is fairly short, so I would recommend buying it on sale.  I got it as part of a humble bundle myself so I don't feel like I overpaid, but the full price on Steam does feel a little bit high to me for only 5 hours of gameplay.

Posted: December 8, 2015
												Interesting puzzle game. No explainations or hints. Just problems in your face. Deal with it.The story makes no sense and is completely irrelvant to the experience, which is a bit sad as I think it was trying to be deep and mysterious. It seems deep and mysterious, and it is, but the visuals carry it, not the story.It glitched out on me once, making a puzzle impossible to do. I came back later to make one last attempt and it was different. Strangest glitch ever. And it wasn't just me seeing things I didn't see last time. Weird things that were there last time were gone, and a broken thing wasn't broken any more. Was it part of the game? Was I meant to give up and turn it off to solve the puzzle? Who knows.To make it stranger still, having now completed the game, I realise there's a way to get through it without even going to that gltiched out room. Bizarre. There seems to be a few ways to progress sometimes, though there may only be one way the leads to progress and the others send you backwards. I had one instance of that, which sent me through the glitch room. I get the feeling there was probably a handful of time I could have gone the "wrong" way and ended up going backwards. Funny thing about this game is you're never sure about anything, which both adds to and takes away from the experience. Mostly it was a good thing. Adds to the dream like quality of the experience.However, having said that, it's not as dream like as it could have been, but again, there's no explaination going in about what's happening, what should happen, or what you should do about it, so it's hard to say what they were going for.It makes slightly more sense by the end and is an interesting journey. I made it through without a walkthrough, which is the only sense of accomplishment you'll get out of it. If you cheat, the experiencce won't be worthwhile in my opinion.Overall I liked it, and I do recommend it, however having just finished it, the experience wasn't as rewarding as I was hoping. [Slight Story Spoiler! I don't say what the story is, I just say what it isn't, which may ruin the mystery of it]I think it's mainly the story that ruined it for me. It tried so hard to have one, and while it's easy to understand, it's hard to understand how the game is related to it, or why it was a story worth telling.In my opinion it would have been a lot better if they went for a trippy, hard to understand story. Something that can be interpreted in a lot of ways. Something that makes a point and leaves you nodding slowing during the end credits, rubbing your chin, thinking about love, life and the space time continuum. But no. I think that's what they wanted me to be doing, but it wasn't happening.

												Mind: Path to Thalamus is a first-person, exploratation, puzzle game that focuses on changing weather and time to shape the environment around you.  The story, not so much engrossing, is interesting to a point.  Voice acting was more or less average.  Soundtrack was serene and elegantly composed. Furthermore, this level from what I gathered was the ONLY one in the game where if you messed up, you had no choice but to start over.  I understand and appreciate it when puzzle games don't take you by the hand and help you every step of the way but with this case, it was incredibly frustrating not knowing a mistake you made in the puzzle was irreversible. 7/10

Posted: January 11, 2016
												Mind: Path to Thalamus is a pretty game.  Sadly, that's about all it has going for it.In terms of puzzles and mechanics it has a nice array of ideas and tools, even given it's one-button gameplay.  However these are sometimes inconsistent and sometimes only used once.  It would be much nicer to see a definitive set of rules that the player could learn to exploit and understand.  Notably: The reflections don't always tell the truth and The night-orb is only ever used to light things up once to name just two.The game's story is also a little bit all over the place.  Its beginning and end seem like completely different games, and the game which caught my interest initially, with a strong opener and an amazing sequence a few levels in, turned out to flop by the end.  Oddly, the final level is one of the best, most interesting, and most thematic, but when you solve that level the game changes back to it's new style, which just isn't very good.The landscapes are very pretty, and the terrain and objects are well rendered.  The music goes along well with the piece and has a few great tracks.All in all, if you really want to see something great while you walk around it's an okay buy, but I feel you'd probably be better off buying something more coherent.

												+Puzzles are often pretty good and conveyance is good (i.e. they aren't just frusturated banging your head against a wall until it breaks)+Environments and (most) assets look really good, especially at night, where they get downright gorgeous+Music is quite good, if a bit forgettable+Since it's supposed to be set in the mind or something, parts of it are appropriately surreal+There's a boss fight (in a puzzle game, yeah) that's pretty intense and fun-Story is kind of silly and overdone, doesn't match the setting, and gets pretentious and shoves its head up its own♥♥♥♥♥at some points-Only one voice actor kind of kills immersion (There's some kind of self-referential line about this in the game, but I don't think that excuses it)-Gameplay is kind of inconsistent, at a certain point the mirror-deflection stuff just gets dropped for the main puzzle mechanics and never shows up again-Price is a smidge high, used to be a lot worse though (Also, why is it the "Enhanced Edition"? I don't see any other version)I really wish Steam had a 'mixed' recommendation, since Thalamus has some pretty good puzzles and looks good, but it seems like a game made by an art team with one solid gameplay member. By that I mean the game looks damn good, the music is good, the puzzles are good, but the story is lame and forced and only one person stepped up to do the VA work (which was admittedly not terrible). I also have the suspicion that the devs worked on two different concepts for their puzzle system and rather than taking one and going with it or blending the two together, they just split the game up and gave each mechanic one part with just a jarring switch in the middle.5/10, buy it if you really want it, but I wouldn't recommend it to someone who isn't interested.

												[Edit] After the release of the "Enhanded Edition" (a monikor I do not agree with in this case) I felt the need to return to this game to see what all changed and I'm very not pleased. First off, there is seemingly only 2 new puzzles, both are astoundingly easy and primarily used to teach you how certain mechanics work (one of which never actually appeared to come up again). But the real disaster here is the completely altered ending sequence, with the original final level being removed. The part of the game that I really enjoyed. Now it's just a middle of the run, less than super interesting environmental puzzle game.[Original write-up]MIND is pretty short all things considered, and most of the puzzles along the way are pretty straight forward until the last 2 chapters, and has a few odd collision and geometry issues, but none of that matters. What matters is the interesting story of redemption of a man longing for forgiveness for letting his sister die in a disaster. Story is simply well done, and all comes together in a brilliant last 20 minutes when the entire game is turned on it's head and borders on breaking the fourth wall.In those last 20 minutes, I went from merely enjoying the game, to absolutely loving what MIND has done here.

												I've got to be honest - I put off playing this game for a while due to some negative reviews on community boards, but I finally broke down and decided to buy it and give it a shot for myself... and I am actually REALLY glad that I did. The game is downright gorgeous. It runs well even on my Intel HD Graphics Card laptop. The puzzles are actually simple in design, but complex to solve at times, which is a great balance. While the mechanics themselves are simple, it's the order of the puzzles which provides the challenge - it requires you to actually use your brain! The story was pleasing, and I actually found myself emotionally effected at times, be it fear, sadness, awe, terror or joy. Few games can cycle a player through those emotions, and Path to Thalamus did a fantastic job. My only criticism of this entire game is a repeat of what others have said, that at times the voice acting can be a little "dry". It's not that it was terrible, but there were many times that I just didn't fell immersed by the narration. IE: It wasn't believable. That said, it was not a bother at all, and without the voice overs, the game would have been less, so I am actually glad that they were there. All in all, if you are looking for a challenging yet relaxing game, with beautiful visuals, great music, a pretty well though-out story, and a satisfying conclusion, this is probably something you will enjoy. Definitely recommended.

												This is very "specific" game. It is like [Story-Driven-But-Hidden] and [No-One-Explains-You-Anything]. Really, in the first level it took me a lot of time to understand what I have to do to proceed. I like the visuals a lot (though some parts are beautiful but some parts also ugly) but I don't like the voice acting.  Overall puzzles are easy to not-so-easy but not very challenging.Pros:- Beautiful visuals (mostly).- Good music.- Interesting journey through various landscapes.- Very good atmosphere.Cons:- Voice acting (That guy who voiced the narrator is hard to listen to - it is somewhat silent).- Stupid nad unintuitive movement in the menu - I'm used to press ESC when I want to return to menu one level up but in this game it just kill the game and you have to start it again (an that happens when you press ESC ANYTIME in menu).- It is not possible to change graphics or whatever when you are playing - you have to leave the game to the setting menu, change what you want and then start chapter again.

content:
Posted: January 3, 2015
												Mind: Path to Thalamus is a puzzle game whose main mechanic involves neuron-like orbs being placed into circles which change the environment. For example, standing in or placing an orb in a rain-circle will raise all piers to a higher level and the time-circle will restore parts of the old ruins. With a limited amount of orbs, this makes for some quite tricky puzzling at the latter levels.The best part of Path to Thalamus is without a doubt the expansive, gorgeous vistas present in it's level design. Never have I felt such a sense of scale from a game. It's got beautifully realized infinite plains of sand covered in a shallow layer of water, grand hills stretching everywhere, a fascinating crystallized representation of neurons in a brain, magically floating islands and a ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ amazing frozen tsunami. It feels like walking inside of a particularly expressive art installation. Mind's story is serviceable, but perhaps not it's strongest point. It's a shame they settled for only using one voice actor, because the emotional impact suffers a lot when the dead relative have the same voice as you, even if it has an in-universe explanation. The ending is interesting, and I can appreciate what they were going for, but the story as a whole is not one of Mind's strong points.In conclusion, if you enjoyed Dear Esther's visuals, but wished it was much more spectacular and involved a challenge, then I'd recommend Mind: Path to Thalamus to you.

												Frustrating and a bit broken. I'm sure I would love it if I could get past the annoyances... Here's how my "0.2 hours" went.Load it up, want to play fullscreen... no idea how to do that. I had to check the Steam forums to find you press Alt-Enter to go fullscreen, which is mentioned nowhere. A small issue, but one that has no reason to exist.Start, OK, looks good! Except, the controls are shown but only the movement controls are labelled in English, the rest are in some other language... Never mind, continue.Little while later, I decide I want to turn the subtitles on so I don't miss things. Took a while to figure out you have to HOLD Escape, not just press it. That's another little issue. The menu helpfully shows a preview of the subtitle text, except it displays in the wrong size until I fuss with it for a while. OK? I go to resume... but it doesn't resume, it puts me back at the start of the chapter I was in. Again, not the end of the world but all these little things are adding up.I get to some voiceover, and... the subtitle is broken. It doesn't show what the voice was saying, only the first line in a really broken way.At that point, I gave up.
